subject: Coming In October...
event: ... is the latest crossgenre anthology from Gardner Dozois and yours truly. This one is called DOWN THESE STRANGE STREETS, and in its pages you'll find another all star roster of writers, with a mixture of urban fantasy, science fiction, hardboiled mystery, noir, paranormal romance, historicals, and fantasy PI stories. The lineup includes a Lord John novella from Diana Gabaldon, a SPQR story by John Maddox Roberts, a True Blood story by Charlaine Harris, a Garrett tale from Glen Cook, an Edge story from Melinda Snodgrass, a Gordianus yarn from Steven Saylor, an incredible WWII mystery novella by Bradley Denton, a Joe Lansdale story than can only be described as Gonzo Lovecraft, and wonderful contributions from Carrie Vaughn, Conn Iggulden, Simon R. Green, Laurie R. King, Lisa Tuttle, M.L.N. Hanover, Patricia Briggs,and S.M. Stirling. The complete table of contents: - "The Bastard Stepchild" (introduction), by George R.R. Martin - "Death by Dahlia," by Charlaine Harris - "The Bleeding Shadow," by Joe R. Lansdale - "Hungry Heart," by Simon R. Green - "Styx and Stones," by Steven Saylor - "Pain and Suffering," by S.M. Stirling - "It's Still the Same Old Story," by Carrie Vaughn - "The Lady Is a Screamer," by Conn Iggulden - "Hellbender,"by Laurie R. King - "Shadow Thieves," by Glen Cook - "No Mystery, No Miracle," by Melinda Snodgrass - "The Difference Between a Puzzle and a Mystery," by M.L.N. Hanover - "The Curious Affair of the Deodand," by Lisa Tuttle - "Lord John and the Plague of Zombies," by Diana Gabaldon - "Beware the Snake," by John Maddox Roberts - "In Red, With Pearls," by Patricia Briggs - "The Adakian Eagle," by Bradley Denton Look for DOWN THESE STRANGE STREETS at your favorite bookstore this fall.

comments.article:
Some of my favorite authors!

That looks like alot of fun.

Brilliant News, Ser. Will rush to the bookshop immediately. Does that never-before published story the cover hints at include dancing dragons ? Just joking (:-) No real fan of the story would want to rush you.

P.S. I recently noticed a new magazine with collectible dragon miniatures on the newsstand. But the series does not include licensed Dany-Dragons, it seems, though to me it would seem a good business idea.
Not that I have any complaints about the anthologies I'm in, but--maaaan! I never get to be in any of the cool anthologies! :) Looks terrific, can't wait to read it!

Good stuff, late last year after I completed my quest to have a complete set of Wild Card books I began my quest to have a complete set of all anthologies that feature a story from you! I'll get this one first run, thanks!
comments.subject: Cool!

comments.article: cool - there are a lot of other authors listed that I've been meaning to check out for a while. will definitely keep an eye out for this book in the fall :)
"Gonzo Lovecraft" is the best phrase I've ever heard.

Another great collection of authors, though I admit, for some reason I had had it in my head that Howard Waldrop would contribute something. Was he tenatively announced earlier, or did I just make it up? Probably just a sign that I need to re-read "The Ugly Chickens" or "Man-Mountain Gentian".

Is the Hanover part of the Black Sun's Daughter canon?
Howard was supposed to be in the book, yes, but he is still writing THE MOON WORLD and had to drop out.
is "The Bastard Stepchild" an egg and dunk story?
It's not a story at all.  It's an introduction.  See where it says "Introduction" in the table of contents?

comments.upictitle: b i o m e c h a n i c a l: lala
comments.article:
Um...want!

October seems so far away!

Oo! Thanks for the heads up! Going to add this to my Amazon wishlist, since I have to wait until October. I am a huge fan of Briggs and Gabaldon (and you, too, obviously ^_~). Anthologies are also an awesome way to be introduced to other authors, so I'm looking forward to checking out the many others I haven't tried yet! I'm a big-time Urban Fantasy fan. :) This will be available for the Kindle, I hope!

Good ser, I was quite hoping for something like this. Urban fantasy, gonzo lovecraft, and paranormal romance sandwiched between the covers of one book? It's almost too much for a fan such as myself.

Only thing missing is a Wild Cards entry! But I can without this time I guess as Lisa Tuttle and Melinda Snodgrass are representin.

Keep up the pace and the good work!
I was really hoping for something else when I read the title of this post. ;)
What is up with that poor woman's legs? They appear to be bending backwards?

I agree. Her stance is such that she should be falling over into her super-natural "insert-here".

The artist did however, manage to get her hips over her feet, but the bone structure on her lower legs are reminiscent of a goat.

Though she could be the daughter of Pan or some such silliness and it's a genetic attribute. What an amusing story that would be. The daughter of Pan loose on the city streets and only Vampire Von Vamper can bring her down.
comments.subject: Oh dear...

comments.article:
Wow! This looks awesome! Will definitely have to get it once I have enough money (my bank has been telling me for months now that it'll come soon but I'm sure March 1st will finally be the day!)

I do however think that your name should have been in a larger font!

Good job, ser!
But it looks like another fun collection of shorts. Thanks for the heads-up.

Evil twisted writer! Though I suppose that's part of why grrm's stories are so diabolically enjoyable...

This looks like a great collection though, I'm glad to see Lisa Tuttle with a new story.  Is there any chance the two of you will ever write more Windhaven books?
comments.subject: Coming In October....

comments.article:
Thank you for the news, Ser! Here in Italy we got, finally, the first and long awaited "Wild Cards" book translation. Great! Now I hope that some enlightened publisher will give us the translation of all the anthologies edited by you & GD. Keep up this publishing pace, Ser! This is a dream.

And I'm so sorry I don't understand the basics of American Football, otherwise I could enjoy your Jets and Giants posts. Only soccer here ^_^'
comments.subject: Great News!

comments.article:
Dear Ser,

I felt the need to create a LiveJournal account expressly to comment on this new anthology. I have been an avid fan of yours since "Fevre Dream" and have thoroughly enjoyed most anything you've ever worked on. I mean, "Beauty and the Beast"?! I picked up the DVDs as soon as they were available to replace my badly damaged VCR recordings :X

Anyway, I just wanted to express my gratitude for you continuing to lend your invaluable experience to projects such as these. However, I'm more than a bit disappointed that Charlaine Harris is the headliner. No offense to Ms. Harris (love the True Blood HBO series!) but she is no "American Tolkien." I know she's quite prolific, writing and publishing a book or more a year, but quantity does not equal quality.

You are truly a humble man to allow your name (and the often thankless task of editing!) to be in such small font at the bottom. Your dectractors should put that in their pipes and smoke it! Truly, Ser, I salute you and your magnanimity. Thank you for having this blog where fans can send you well-wishes: I'd never think of cluttering your email with something as silly as fanmail :)

Theresa A.
comments.subject: hello!

comments.article: Not sure about that cover, other than that can't wait.
comments.subject: Take cover

comments.article: Yah, that woman does have weird legs ... but e've gotta wait until October? *picks up chicken soup and settles down to wait*
i am always impressed with the amount of different projects you are able to work on at a time.  not to mention that they are all terrific quality to boot.  keep 'em coming, ser!
comments.subject: where do you find the time?

comments.article:
I've been looking forward to this since I saw it listed somewhere as coming "(((soon)))" a month or two back.

Some of the story titles are indeed awesome...the title given your introduction as well, ser! I can't wait to read it. I must confess to being a bit disappointed though: when are we going to see your good friend Shawn Speakman contribute to one of your anthologies? After reading the sample chapters of The Dark Thorn awhile back, I'd have thought an anthology with some urban fantasy like this was right up his alley. Maybe next time?

Which leads to my other question: how long does it typically take to put one of these anthologies together from concept to publication?
comments.subject: Finally...

comments.article:
New anthology is phenomenal news ser!!!! This is big year publishing for you, yes? FORT FREAKS and then new book you announce DOWN THOSE STRANGE STREETS. First I think FORT FREAK is most exciting but then I see this!

Is especcially nice to see more work from WILD CARDS authors. I notice Carrie Vaughn and Melinda Snodgrass of series. Of Carrie Vaughn I am great fan since sister Mila lends to me KITTY novels.

I am wondering if you considered anthology of TUF VOYAGING wrote by other authors. Universe is rich for writing more I think.

I am always marveled by the ability of a good Editor. Do you edit your own work, Ser? Feast for Crows was my favorite of your game of thrones books. I think I've read all your work but there was something about that one. I just felt right THERE alongside the characters as the world was explored, conversations were had, and various fodder was liquidated (I hope that doesn't count as a spoiler?). Since you're such a prolific editor, can one assume you edit your own novels too? Is it hard? And do you have any tips for an aspiring spec fiction writer? More specifically I am focused on chess-based, mathematical, steampunk fic.
comments.subject: Editorial work

comments.article: The fangirl in me objects to Charlaine Harris' name being bigger than Patricia Briggs'. But I suppose with the success of True Blood, it was inevitable. ;)
